TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants belong to the NORP minority living in GPE and they are currently NORP nationals . The applicant in application no . CARDINAL , Mr István Fehér ( “ the first applicant ” ) , was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The applicant in application no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG ( “ the second applicant ” ) , was born in DATE and lives in ORG . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant informed ORG that he had acquired NORP citizenship on DATE . Referring to LAW , he indicated that he did not wish to give up his NORP citizenship and wanted to continue living and working in GPE as a NORP citizen respecting the LAW and the laws of GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG asked the first applicant to complete and return a notice confirming his loss of NORP citizenship .
CARDINAL . On DATE he informed ORG that he was not willing to comply with the above request , as the relevant provisions of LAW DATE were contrary to LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE , in the absence of any reply , the first applicant reiterated his arguments . He also referred to the fact that he had not been formally notified of his loss of NORP citizenship .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the first applicant that the relevant authorities had been notified that he had lost NORP citizenship on the basis of his letter indicating that he had acquired NORP citizenship . He was reminded that his NORP passport and identity card had become invalid and had to be returned to the authorities . In cases where persons had voluntarily opted for the citizenship of a different ORG , they lost their NORP citizenship ex lege . The NORP authorities were therefore not required to issue a formal certificate to that effect .
CARDINAL . In a letter the first applicant asked his local authority , ORG , why he had not been notified along with the other electors of an upcoming parliamentary election scheduled for DATE .
CARDINAL . In its response of CARDINAL DATE ORG informed him that the law obliged it to delete from the electoral register all persons who had lost NORP citizenship .

CARDINAL . In a different letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG informed the first applicant that it had been notified by ORG on DATE that he had lost NORP citizenship . He was advised to address his request for a certificate of his permanent address to the relevant department of the police , who kept a register of foreigners permanently residing in GPE .

CARDINAL . The first applicant ’s employer made his continued employment conditional upon his compliance with the statutory obligations imposed on foreigners residing in GPE and his adherence to the social security insurance scheme .
CARDINAL . The first applicant experienced health problems owing to stress resulting from the above .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant informed ORG that she had sworn an oath of allegiance and obtained NORP citizenship on DATE . She further declared that she was not renouncing her NORP citizenship and that she wished to continue living in GPE and respecting its laws .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant asked ORG to issue her with a NORP citizenship certificate . She reiterated her intention to remain a NORP national and argued that under LAW , no one could be deprived of NORP citizenship against his or her will .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG advised the second applicant that under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) of LAW DATE , persons who had voluntarily acquired a different ORG ’s citizenship automatically lost NORP citizenship . ORG therefore issued no certificates in that respect .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant asked her local authority , ORG , why she had not been notified along with the other electors of the upcoming parliamentary election .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the second applicant that it had been notified by ORG that she had lost NORP citizenship . On that basis , and in accordance with the relevant law , ORG had deleted her from the electoral register . She was therefore disallowed from voting in the parliamentary election on DATE . Her complaint was dismissed as being totally devoid of merit , with reference to the fact that she had lost NORP citizenship .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant complained to ORG that she had received no official notification of her loss of NORP citizenship . She was thereby prevented from seeking redress from the NORP authorities .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the second applicant that , following her letter of CARDINAL DATE , it had notified the relevant authorities , namely the local authority in which she lived , the police , the tax and customs offices , and the institutions in charge of social and public health insurance , that she had lost NORP citizenship . The law did not oblige ORG to issue a certificate confirming loss of citizenship , as it took effect ex lege .

CARDINAL . The Levice District Police repeatedly informed the second applicant that , following her loss of NORP citizenship , she was required by law to return her national identity card . She replied that she had received no official notification of her loss of NORP citizenship and still considered herself to be a NORP national . She pointed out that a group of members of parliament had initiated proceedings to determine whether the relevant statutory provisions conformed to the guarantees of the LAW .

CARDINAL . NORP The police also asked the second applicant to return her NORP passport , which had become invalid following her loss of NORP citizenship . Her failure to do so was susceptible of constituting a minor offence , for which a fine up to MONEY ( ORG ) might be imposed .
CARDINAL . The second applicant replied that she considered herself to be a NORP citizen and therefore saw no reason for returning her identity card and passport .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW , the circumstances under which persons acquire and lose NORP citizenship are to be stipulated by law .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides than no person may be deprived of NORP citizenship against his or her will .
CARDINAL . LAW DATE ( PERSON o štátnom občianstve PERSON republiky ) , as amended with effect from DATE , contains the following relevant provisions .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ) provides :
“ Citizenship of GPE may only be lost :
( a ) by means of release upon one ’s own request ;
( b ) upon acquiring a foreign ORG ’s citizenship by way of an explicit expression of intent . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that a person loses NORP citizenship on DATE he or she voluntarily acquires the citizenship of a foreign ORG by way of an explicit expression of intent such as a request , declaration or any other action directed at acquiring the citizenship of a foreign ORG .

CARDINAL . Subsections ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of section CARDINAL provide exceptions to the above , namely where a person acquires foreign citizenship ( i ) by marriage to a foreign national , provided that the person acquires the foreign citizenship during the marriage , or ( ii ) by birth .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , persons who lose their NORP citizenship under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) are obliged to notify their local district office without delay .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) read in conjunction with section CARDINAL ) obliges the relevant district office to notify the following authorities of the person ’s loss of NORP citizenship under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) : the local authority in which the person resides , the police , the tax and customs offices , and the institutions in charge of social and public health insurance .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINALb(CARDINAL)(d ) provides that a minor offence has been committed if a person fails to comply with the obligation under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , namely to notify the district office about their loss of NORP citizenship without delay .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINALb(CARDINAL ) renders such an offence punishable by a fine of up to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE members of parliament claimed before ORG that sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL)b , CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , GPE ) and CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE were contrary to LAW , LAW , and LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG at its plenary session declared the motion admissible .
CARDINAL . The proceedings on the merits are pending .
CARDINAL . LAW ( PERSON No . CARDINAL ) entered into force in respect of GPE on DATE . Its relevant provisions read as follows :
CARDINAL . Each State shall determine under its own law who are its nationals .

CARDINAL . NORP This law shall be accepted by other GPE in so far as it is consistent with applicable international conventions , customary international law and the principles of law generally recognised with regard to nationality .
The rules on nationality of each ORG shall be based on the following principles :
( a ) everyone has the right to a nationality ;
( b ) statelessness shall be avoided ;
( c ) no one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his or her nationality ; ...

CARDINAL . The rules of a ORG on nationality shall not contain distinctions or include any practice which amount to discrimination on the grounds of sex , religion , race , colour or national or ethnic origin . ...
CARDINAL . A State Party may not provide in its internal law for the loss of its nationality ex lege or at the initiative of ORG except in the following cases :
( a ) NORP voluntary acquisition of another nationality ; ...
ORG shall ensure that decisions relating to the acquisition , retention , loss , recovery or certification of its nationality contain reasons in writing .

ORG shall ensure that decisions relating to the acquisition , retention , loss , recovery or certification of its nationality be open to an administrative or judicial review in conformity with its internal law . ...
The provisions of this Convention shall not limit the right of a ORG to determine in its internal law whether :
( a ) its nationals who acquire or possess the nationality of another ORG retain its nationality or lose it ; ... ”

CARDINAL . With effect from CARDINAL DATE LAW ( Law no . LV of DATE ) was amended . Its section CARDINAL ) provides for naturalisation , upon request and on preferential terms , of non - NORP nationals with an ascendant of NORP nationality or who can plausibly show their NORP origins and provide proof of their knowledge of the NORP language .
